title: Carole King's "Tapestry" album typeface
content:
Longshot here, but a client would like to try and replicate the display font from Carole King's landmark album [http://images.barnesandnoble.com/images/9180000/9189509.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150321004907/http:/images.barnesandnoble.com/images/9180000/9189509.jpg).  
Doubtful that it's actually a typeface, more like hand drawn piece of art. But, I have to ask...

Anybody out there know of a font that's even remotely close?

Thanks in advance for any replies!  
Dr. Theopolis
author: DocTheop

comments.content:
Here are your caps - but this digitization doesn't have a lower case. I expect it is a font, but may not be digitized in the form you see it.

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/hihretrofonts/schnorr-gestreckt/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150321004907/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/hihretrofonts/schnorr-gestreckt/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/hihretrofonts/schnorr-gestreckt/")

A search on myfonts.com for "nouveau" will turn up some similar fonts, many from Solotype.

Ah there ya go. I just found Ambrosia in my Art Nouveau fonts Dover book but I was beaten to the punch.
Wow. Simply "wow". Thank you both! I would have spun my wheels for hours!
Has Carole King got six toes in that photo?
